data.title: Le grand jeu
data.meta_description: This classic French battle between love, fate and bewitching passion set a pattern for later hits such as Casablanca, writes Philip French
data.text: This classic example of pre-war French "poetic realism", directed by the great Belgian movie-maker Jacques Feyder, centres on an upper-class playboy business man (Pierre Richard-Willm) with financial problems being compelled to leave Paris and his high-maintenance lover Florence, and join the Foreign Legion in Morocco. A couple of years later as a reckless, hard-drinking sergeant, he meets a beautiful prostitute, the amnesiac Irma who's Florence's double, though their hair colour and voices are different. Can they be the same woman? A story of love, death and fate, this truly adult movie has a great cast that includes Marie Bell as both Florence and Irma, Charles Vanel as a vile hotelier and Françoise Rosay as a compassionate barmaid who predicts the hero's troubled future. Lazare Meerson's sets range from art deco Paris to Moroccan nightclubs, the photography is by Harry Stradling (later to win awards for both Pygmalion and My Fair Lady), and the movie looks forward to Pépé le Moko and Casablanca, as well as Vertigo.
